name: Port of Call
description: Imagine waking up on a small dock with no recollection of who you are or how you got there. The first person you find is a grumpy, old man who enlists you to work on his ferry boat which seems to have materialized behind you.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP/Windows 7/Vista/8 Processor: Intel i3 Memory: 1024 MB RAM Graphics: Intel integrated DirectX: Version 9.0 Storage: 326 MB available space Additional Notes: Optimal with headphones
recommended_requirements: OS: Windows XP/Windows 7/Vista/8 Processor: Intel i5 Memory: 2048 MB RAM Graphics: Intel integrated DirectX: Version 9.0 Storage: 326 MB available space Additional Notes: Optimal with headphones

reviews.review_text: This is a very short, but interesting little game. You wake up at a pier, not knowing who or where you are. The old man invites you to enter his boat, and then an original story unfolds. The dialogue is very well written, and the story drew me very easy into this game. Which proved necessary in order to get real enjoyment, since neither the graphics nor the audio is up to the level of the story. At the end the game left me in disarry for a moment, since it is rather grim and unsettling.  But since this is a free game, there's no reason not to recommend it. Furthermore, it comes with seven achievements which can be unlocked easily, so for anyone looking for 100% games this is a must. Do play it twice: the story made much more sense to me on my second playthrough, and the game is really short.   Recommend to everyone interested in something slightly different

You wake up on a dock. You board a strange boat. You have to meet people to retrieve their tickets to satisfy the captain. But everything is strange: between the passengers with masks, items floating in the air and the shadows, you're asking yourself if you're in the realm of Death or it's just a dream...  Port of Call is a small adventure game, in a cartoonish style, where you're trying to find who you are and why you need to meet these passengers. Listening to their stories is also interesting because they hold the key to your identity.  The soundtrack is good, like the graphics that are so reassuring and freakening at the same time: while it's not a dark game, when you see floating stuffs, a huge toy sheet and shadows, you're asking yourself what's happening. You understand quickly that you're maybe dead but then, why are you collecting tickets? Shouldn't you be a simple passenger?  Anyway, there are no puzzles there: apart speaking, finding a teddy bear and mixing drinks, you're just confronted to a poor gameplay. Yet, the dialogues here are important if you want to understand the story and find answers. The quest for the pencils and the paintings is also a nice bonus, though that for the paintings, it's very easy.  The main problem of the game is the fact that you have an hard time to find a menu, you have to press Escape to make it appear and to quit properly the game. The screen title lacks options.  But there is another problem with the game that will bother AZERTY users. The game is set with WASD keys, without ZQSD alternative or arrows. While the fix for comfort is to move the mouse and to keep pressing on W, as it's not natural to press the W instead of the Z, once you're releasing the key, you have some seconds to remind yourself, that no, the key you're so used to press isn't the same.  Other than that, I enjoyed the experience. And it's free with achievements!

Short, eery, yet undoubtedly enjoyable free-to-play game.  You start on a dock, boarding a creepy boat and have to collect people's tickets. Different objects appear and dissapear, there's floating books, passengers wearing masks, and silhouettes of dead passengers. You make a final decision at the end to join the dead in the afterlife or regain your life and wake back up in what sounds like a hospital room.  Rate: 8/10

“The destination is but an incidental consequence of the journey.”    Port of Call is a narrative exploration game developed and published by the company Underdog Games.    Pro & contra:    + Immersive short-form storytelling.   o Occasional use of musical background and sounds.   - Low quality graphics with some questionable elements.    Summary:    Port of Call represents straight-forward and interesting journey of self-discovery. The only drawback is the graphical presentation. It feels rushed and would have needed more attention, in order to give the game a unique look that supports the narrative.   Recommended for achievement hunters and curious explorers.     Achievements:    Estimated time for 100% completion: +30 minutes  Singleplayer achievements: 7 Multiplayer achievements: none

For a proper judgment I have to ignore it's a free game and just evaluate whether it's worth playing. That's why I gave it a thumbs down.  Playing a free low-skill tech demo still occupies your time, and unless you consider that worthless, you can skip Port of Call without having to worry that you miss anything.  This game proves nothing more that the dev has very basic technical game-making skills. The story writing and such is slightly below OK. The story is like a copy of a witty story with surprise twists and then making it fully predictable, removing anything special and appealing from it, so it's bascially totally unspectacular. Also, the dialogues, while occasionally providing choices, not only have no effect on the progress of events, but often don't even result in different responses. This was especially bad towards the end, when the resolution forces its course even if your dialogue choices go totally against it, and that was like the seal of truth on what I perceived before.  There are achievements for doing stuff of no consequence or even not making sense. You collect crayons that are lying around. Why? Why should you pick them up? You have no need for them, no incentive to pick them up.  Even so much as different text colors for you and others was too much to ask. Your text is placed slightly lower than NPC text, that's all.  I don't know, maybe some people actually find this entertaining (especially if you have never experienced remarkable writing), but generally a game published on Steam should be focused on the player, not the developer. This is like: 'Look, I can make a game with kind of a story. Please take half an hour to admire that. I offer it for free, so you cannot complain no matter what.'  I feel like I watched a commercial. Or participated in a beta-testing run.  I recently played 'the static speaks my name' and I found that a tiny bit better due to how it at least made me ponder a little on what message it might be trying to convey.
It's a cool short game. The dialoug in the game is great, along with the story to accompany it. Just an all around great small game. Definitely recommend playing!

Port of Call is an excellent atmospheric, chilling indie game. I would briefly like to say that unlike many other indie games it offers a different meaning to a sense of storyline and thrilling perspective. It is a small amount of MB to download which is a huge plus to those with minimal disk space. Realistically, you just HAVE TO play the game and experience yourself how good it is. One of these games doesn't come around too often.  Aside from the rest, the only con I have to this game is that it has a tendendancy to freeze and sometimes crash, at least for me and on my Mac. Don't know about how or what can fix it but overall, the rest aside, i strongly recommend it.

This neat little game, which was announced at the 2014 E3 College Game Competition, is definitely worth checking out.  'Port of Call' begins with the protagonist, who is unnamed and suffers from amnesia, waking up on a dock and boarding a ship that seemed to materialize out of nothing. It is helmed by a mysterious hooded man who towers over you, and the story unfolds as you meet with the other passengers aboard the ship.  The game, in the same style as 'Gone Home' or 'Dear Esther', is a walking sim, with atmosphere and narrative being the focus. While the game itself doesn't bring anything groundbreaking to the genre, it is a neat little story that you can knock out as you're having your morning cup of coffee.  Plus it's free, and who doesn't like free things?  Underdog Games are still finding their feet (this being their first release), but this is a game worth checking out, and if you like walking sims, you won't be disappointed.
A heart-wrenchingly beautiful way to kill some spare time, 'Port of Call' will take you on a journey of revelations and will leave you with a weighty choice.   10/10 Would come close to crying again.
